note.p: Education: Westminster School; Christ Church, Oxford; BA (1701), MA (1704), incorporated at Cambridge (1715); Middle Temple (admitted 1700)

Career: Ordained deacon and priest (1704); Chaplain to his father (1704); Prebendary and Archdeacon of Rochester (1704-1720); Vicar of Boxley, Kent (1705-1720); Rector of Stone, Kent (1707-1720); Chaplain to Queen Anne (1712-1714); Chaplain to George I (1714-1717); Canon of Winchester (1712-1720); Canon of Westminster (1713-1720)
Sources: Bulloch's Roll; Venn; Foster; Thomas; DNB (father's entry); MT; Barker
References: Neil Chambers, 'Letters From the President: the Correspondence of Sir Joseph Banks' in NR 1999 vol 53 pp 27-57
Marie Boas Hall, 'The Early Years of the Royal Society', review of Michael Hunter, Establishing the New Science: the Experience of the Early Royal Society in NR 1990 vol 44 pp 265-268
Christopher Hill, 'The Intellectual Origins of the Royal Society - London or Oxford?' in NR 1968 vol 23 pp 144-156
Douglas McKie, 'The Origins and Foundation of the Royal Society of London' in NR 1960 vol 15 pp 1-37
